page.title: 07Great Shelford
page.content: Great Shelford appeared to be quite a rich village. We came to this conclusion through the questionaires which had shown that most people had either retired or were still working. Nobody we spoke to was unemployed and as it was a monday most people would have been at work. On the outskirts by the farms, we saw many fields: wheat was the main crop. {Transport}was quite busy and by the Great Shelford post office there were a lot of cars followed by lorries and frequent buses going into Cambridge. The{railway}line to London (Liverpool Street) ran throungh the centre of the village and the station stayed open till 1 am (not popular with the local villagers who complained of the noise). Just before Shelford, the line to Royston branches off carrying little diesel 'bus-trains'.
